page.title: 02LANDSCAPE
page.content: The area is one of rolling chalk downlands, an attractive typical Southern English landscape with cottages and farms dotted about, and winding lanes crossing the downs. Hedges have been uprooted to make larger fields for cereal growing,but a number of copses have been kept, especially in the north of the area. The disused railway, Winchester Hill Lane and Westbury Park are favourite areas for walking, and wildlife abounds, especially in the latter, where it is common to see deer, foxes, badgers and rabbits. Wild flowers flourish in the uncultivated areas, including cowslips and wild orchids. Unfortunately, the busy A32 road bisects West Meon. A traffic survey in July 1985 showed 63 cars, 26 lorries, 8 vans and 2 motorbikes passing in the space of 30 mins.
